Entry.1: – S.S. Aeneas. Sea very smooth. Sighted land at Melbourne – again at Albury – no stops – about 2000 men aboard. Concert on Christmas Eve. Very Dry one and a poor feed at that. Buried a man at sea about 2 days sail from Australia on
Entry.2: 1915, 4 o’clock. Parade for 2 hours a day. Plenty of fun a board.
Entry.4:
Pillow Fight – Cock fight – Mop Competition – Bun Eating Comp. – Tugo-war. 

Morris
Entry.5:
prize Bun Eating, 10/-.

Very warm for the New Year. 

Boxing Tournament
Entry.7:
Passed the line. Rained very heavy at night.

Boxing
Entry.10: sighted land and many ships – Cape Gardarfui. Persia sunk
Entry.12:
early morning – 12 apostles. Passed several vessels.

Arrived at Suez Saturday night 8.00 Sydney time, 4 o’clock Sunday morning. Arrived at Cairo on Tuesday morn 4 a.m. 9 hours on train 80 miles. Camped Heliopolis Aerodrome 2½ miles outside Cairo – Aeroplanes noticeable alday. Landed on
Entry.16:
Alarm in camp all Regiments called out. Camel corp passed Camp. 

On
Entry.17: scalded both feet went to Luna Park. Treated very kindly. Got about on Crutches until
Entry.18: and from then on - on a stick. Went for a walk to Aerodrome Camp on
Entry.19: first for three weeks. Got many gifts in hospital from Red Cross. Wrote to several of + the workers in Sydney.
Entry.20: Given a box of choc. from Cadburys.
Entry.22:
Got Paid at Aerodrome.

Visited Egyptian Musuem
Entry.24: – Discharged from Luna Park – Went to Montazah – about 120 miles from Cairo 8 miles from Alexandria – 3½ hours journey – on the Coast.
Entry.25: – Wrote letters. Examined by Doctor full Diet.
Entry.26: – Went for a stroll around the grounds, seen a very ancient cave – got a bit of Coral and a few shells.
Entry.27: – Went for a walk to beach.
Entry.28:
– Seen Dentist having teeth attended to.

had a swim in the Mediterraen.
Entry.29: – A splendid Concert – Row in Boat.
Entry.30:
Finished Dental treatment one tooth out – another 
tooth
 swim.

11, 12 & 13 – Wandering about.
Entry.31: - Put in for 14/-. R. Ackett Discharged .
Entry.32:
- Received pay – discharge B Duties.

On
Entry.33: arrived at Cairo 4 o’clock. Taken to Overseas Base Ghezia. Went to Aerodrome Camp to see about mail.
Entry.34: – Got up 6-30 fell in names taken had breakfast, fell in names taken about twenty different times then dismissed. Marched to A details camp.
Entry.35: Taken to Aerodrome Camp back with same reinforcements met Alick & Murphy.
Entry.36: – Rained all night wet to skin.
Entry.38: Sent home silks. Given Sergents Orderly Job, had Photo taken with Alick & Murphy 25 piasters. Wrote Dolly Ralton.
Entry.40: Native funeral – Washing day. Rumors we are going to be transported on Monday morning. Experience in Cairo.
Entry.41: – Revale 2-30 – left Heliopolis 5-00 entrained at Zee Toun 700. Arrived at Alexandria 2-00, marched aboard Saxonia – 3500 troops on anchored in harbour all night.
Entry.42: – Sailed from Alexandria 8-00 o’clock morning steering zig zag course, alarms for submarines very often – Going about with Life belts on.
Entry.43: – Sergents mess – a submarine alarm 9-30 p.m.
Entry.45: Steamed very close to Malta at six o’clock morning.
Entry.46: April, sea with a swell on.
Entry.47: Sailed into Marsailles 10 a.m. – very beautiful scenery – Disembarked 6-00. Camped at Marsailles for the night.
Entry.48: Revalle 5-30 moved off 7-00 entrained at Marsaille nine o’clock – dinner at Orange 1-00 beef & Biscuits & cigarettes – again at 1 o’clock in morning – beautiful scenery all the way.
Entry.49: – Women street cleaners – great reception all along – met Frank Anderson 4618 on same train – Rations 5-00 – very cool. Arrived at Aemien 6-45 a.m. on
Entry.50: – disentrained at Etaples 11 a.m., marched to camp issued with rifle & Banonet parade in afternoon issued with an extra blanket very cool.
Entry.51: – Revalie 6-00 – Breakfast 7-45 – Beef & Jam – Sergents mess – Rained all night.
Entry.56: Raining all day – vapor Bath – went for a walk to village N.E. Etaples.
Entry.57: Still raining & cold – bacon & jam breakfast – Route March to Paris Plage – very cold.
Entry.58: – Mess orderly – Fell in 7-30 went to Bool Ring – Bayonet Charge – Company drill.
Entry.59:
Went to Bull Ring – Bayonet drill – Trench Warfare – inspected by Lady Dudley

& French officers – cold & windy.
Entry.60: Tobacco issue – Snow – Paid 30 francs – Visited Etaples Cemetry –
Entry.63: Breakfast – Round Bread & Jam – Route March – Issued with 1 Pair sock, 1 Underpants – 1 Shirt.
Entry.64: Bulring – Gas lecture – Baynot fighting – Sand bagging – Shift Tents – Raining & windy.
Entry.65: Hail Storm – Parade 8-30 – dismissed 9-15 – fell in 2-00 Rifle exercise – Tea & Rice.
Entry.66:
Parade 7-30, Bulring – Baynot Charge – Company drill – Fine day – Raining all night & next day.

No Parade
Entry.68: Church parade – fine day – Vapor Bath, let down Tents.
Entry.69: Received three letters from home – Picket in Etaples 5 o’clock till 930.
Entry.70:
Anzac day. Church parade – March past – sporting programme.

Zeppelin Raid dropped 5 Bombs 12-15 at night no damage.
Entry.71: Parade 7-30. Boolring – Bayonet charge – company drill – Rapid loading – Fine weather warm – no afternoon parade – Aeroplanes about all night.
Entry.72: Route March morning. Received 2 letters from C.F.G. & one from Bob. Route march afternoon – very warm – all lights out no smoking at all.
Entry.73: Parade 7-30 Bulring – Rapid Loading Company drill – Bayonet charge – one Letter from home – Tents down & disinfected afternoon – wrote to Frank.
Entry.74: Paid 20 Francs – issued 3 Cigarettes – Windy – Fatigue party to Etaples.
Entry.75: Revalie 5-30, Parade 6-00 – Church parade – dropped tents –
Entry.76: Battn. man 12 mts. hard labor insolence.
Entry.77: – parade 7-30 – Bulring – Jam tin bombs – Company drill – Lecture on Bombs & Route march – Rain – Lights still out – Revalie 530.
Entry.78: – Orders read 6-00 – Parade 7-30 Bulring. Open order drill – Bayonet drill – Trench warfare – Storm no parade afternoon.
Entry.79:
– Duty Battalion on Boundry picket – three o’clock till

9 afternoon.
Entry.80: Revalie 5-30 – Parade 10-00 – Fall in 9-00 – Route march – Fall in 1-45 – Lecture on Stokes gun – rifle inspection – inspected by Major Gener. Brothers.
Entry.81: 7-30 – Bulring – Company drill – Lecture Care of arms – Rapid Loading – Bayonet drill.
Entry.83: Church parade – Raining – Parade afternoon – Gas helmet issued.
Entry.84: Bulring – Gas lecture sandbabbing – Disciplin march – Bomb Lecture – Bayonet fighting – issued with chocolate – on Bridge picket – 4 till 10 p.m.
Entry.86: Bulring 7-30. Dismissed from there 11-00 – Tents down – Received letter C.F.G. – Fell in 6-00 a.m. Bulring night attack.
Entry.87: Parade 9-00. Route March – about 12 miles. Parade 1-45 Route march – Tents down.
Entry.88: Mess orderly – Parade 7-30 Bulring – Gas Lecture – Obstacle race – Sand bagging – Bayonet charge. 25 men went up the line.
Entry.90: On Guard in Camp – 24 hrs. sent home card.
Entry.91: issued with necessaries for firing line.
Entry.92: left Etaples 4-00 and disentrained at Steenwerck – march 8 miles to Billet – Stayed in horse Box for the night.
Entry.93: Drafted in A Company 18 Battn. – resting. Gas alarm.
Entry.94: Went to support Trenches at 4-00 A.M. – building dug outs.
Entry.97: innocculated no duties. Bombardment of Equingham – 200 shells. Cigarette issue.
Entry.99: Went to Equingham for bath – paid 20 francs – Fatigue all night building parapets.
Entry.101: Fatigue 4 till 1 o’clock – Dug outs – Moved to Supports 2 o’clock – Fatigue building parapets 8 o’clock till 2 o’clock.
Entry.102: Sleep till 12 o’clock, making ready for firing line – Relieved
Entry.103:
Batt. 9 o’clock – Stand too 2 till 4.

Breakfast 4-30 – Sniping post 7-30 till 11-30 – Dinner 12 o’clock sniping 4 till 8 – Ration Fatigue – Water Fatigue.
Entry.104: On Sentry 12-30 till 2-30 – Stand to – Very cold – Fatigue – Building Dugouts – till 5 p.m. Tea – rest till - Stand to - Exciting aerial Bombardment – on post 8-00 till 10-30.
Entry.105: – on Post 2-30 till 4-00 – Breakfast 4-30. Turned in till 12-00 – Dinner 1-00. Fatigue till 5 o’clock – Tea 5-00. Stand to 8-00 till 9-00. Quiet on all fronts – Stand to 8 till 9-30. On Listening Post 9-30 till 2-00.
Entry.106: – Stand to 2-00 till 4-00. Breakfast – Turned in till 12-00. Dinner – Turned in till tea 5-00 – Quiet on our front – Stand to till 9-30 – on Post 10-30 – 12-30.
Entry.107: – Artillery active on our right – Stand to till 2 till 4. Breakfast 430 – A few shells for fritz – received 10 letters – turned in till 11-30 – Dinner – Fatigue till 5-00. Stand to 8 till 9-00 – On Post 10-30 – 12-30.
Entry.108: – Sniping post 3-30 till 7-30. Turned in till 11-00 – on again 1130 till 4-00 – Received 2 letters – The Germans Brought down one of our planes over their own lines – Our observation Baloon got loose – On Bomb Post 8 till 2-30.
Entry.109:
– Stand to 2-30 till 4-00 – Breakfast – Turned in till 12 – Dinner – Fatigue till 5-00 – Tea – Stand to 8-00 – Stand down 9-00 – Fatigue till 2-30.

On
Entry.110: Post till stand down – Breakfast. Turned in till 12-00 – Fatigue from 4 till 5-30 – Tea – Fatigue till stand to – Germans shell their own Trenches – On Bombing Post from 8-00 till 2-30.
Entry.111: – Breakfast – Turned in till dinner time – Fatigue till 5-00. Plenty of shrapnel about – stand to for half hour – Stand to till 9-00 – On Fatigue till 12-00 – heavy bombardment on our right – Stand to in case of attack.
Entry.112: – On Fatigue till stand to – Breakfast. Turned in till dinner – More Bombs on us no casualties – On Bombing post till 3-00.
Entry.113:
- Sniping 5-30 till 7-30 – more letters.

11-30 till 4 P.M. – Bombardment from 11-00 till 12-30 – about a dozen Casualties – advance on the left 7th Brigade.
Entry.114: – Standing to all night – Turned in 5-30 – till 12-00 – dinner – On Fatigue at 2 o’clock till 4-30 – Tea 5-00 – Packed up after doing 12 days in the trenches – On fatigue from 8-30 till 12-00 – Marched to Billets Just ½ mile from firing line in Support Trenches.
Entry.115: – Slept till 10-00 – breakfast – Rest all day – Went for stroll to Th-- – Turned in 10-00.
Entry.116: – on Fatigue 5-30 till 12-00 on Fire trench – Aerial activity around Bois Grenier – Paid 20 Francs.
Entry.117: – Breakfast 9-00 – Went for walk to Chappel Darmentiers lost the road – Came out at N.Z. Firing line then came to Armentiers and met with terrible wreckage churches etc. On Fatigue 8-30 till 2 o’clock raining.
Entry.119: – innoculated – cold & raining – no duties 24 hrs – Bombardment Ypres & Bois Grenier
Entry.120: – Bombardment @ Ypres eased off – Raining – Packed up ready to move off to 1st line of reserves – On Guard 12 hrs.
Entry.121: – Raining – Went to Erquinghem for Bath & change of clothes – On fatigue for 1½ hrs. – Turned in.
Entry.122: – Fatigue 8-30 till 12-00 – again 2 till 5 – Turned in.
Entry.123: – Fatigue 8-30 till 1-00 – On Guard 9-00 till 5 o’clock.
Entry.124: Gas alarm on our left. Bombardment – Fatigue 1-00 till 5-00 - aerial activity two German planes brought down.
Entry.125: on Fatigue 6-30 – 9.30 – Fatigue 1 till 4 – Bombardment of Ypres, bois Grenier – Stand to from 11-30 till 12-30.
Entry.127:
on Fatigue. Shelled our Supports – Very close shave.

June 21st, on Guard 8-00 a.m. till 8-00 p.m. – Relieved the 20th Battn. – 11-00 – On Post
Entry.129: – On Sniping 8 till 12-00 & 5½ till 10 – Gas alert – Straff on.
Entry.132:
– 12 o’clock. 

Artillery activity all afternoon – On Fatigue – Brought down German Observation Baloons – Arieal activity. Raid on German Trenches – Artillery opens fire 11-30 till 1-00 – In supports – Just like hell – Very narrow escapes – Captured 4 Prisoners &ct.
Entry.133: – Artillery active all day – Raided the German Trenches at midnight under heavy artillery fire for two hours – Inflicted loss & Prisoners brought back – German Baloons destroyered on our right – Raining – Very few casualties.
Entry.139:
– Foot inspection – On Fatigue 7-30 till 4-30.

weeping gas.
Entry.140: – Inspected by Lieut Colonel Wisdom – Ready to move off – inspected again by Major Goodsell.
Entry.145: – On Picket in Erquinghem – Paid 20 Francs.
Entry.147: – Left Erquinghem 9-30 – arrived at Strazeele 5-15 – 14 miles. Foot sore and weary – Passed through several villages – very warm – billetted in a barn just outside Strazeele – Moved off at 9-30
Entry.148: - Marched 11 miles – dinner outside Hazelbrook. On Quarter Guard - 40 hrs.
Entry.149: – moved off 12-30 – marched about 7 miles. Entrained at Arques 5-13.
Entry.150: - to Ameains 3-00. Moved Through the town had breakfast on outskirts Beef & Biscuits. Billeted in very small village – Dinner Beef & Biscuits – 8 mile march.
Entry.153: – Foot inspection – Rifle exercises – Route March.
Entry.154: – Received Letters – Ready to March off – Left Argouves 12-15 – had dinner ¾ hrs. march – Arrived at Cardonetes – 8 miles at 4-00 – had tea only.
Entry.156:
– Mess orderly

ready to leave Cardonettes 1-30. People of this village act like dogs – Marched 5 miles to Rubempre arriving about 4-30 P.M.
Entry.157: – Paid 20 Frances, Sir Douglas Haig &ct. Passed through village.
Entry.158: – Ready to move off 9-45 marched about 6 miles to Warloy-Baillon – Billetted hear orders to remain hear & await other orders ready for action – Pack to be left behind necessaries carried in Haversack.
Entry.159: – Short Route March morning – Fell in Full marching order at 2-45 told we were going to another billetted 3 miles closer to the firing line – but went about 10 mile for a route march coming back about 6-30 – On Billet Guard from 12 till 3.
Entry.160:
– Heavy bombardment all night wounded arriving every few minutes from Albert front. 1½ loves of bread for 10 men first issue for three days – Foot inspection – left Warloy about 6-00 o’clock. Proceeded on to outskirts of Albert where we bivouac for

the night – very cold – Heavy Bombardment all night – Australians attacked Pozieres village. Bombardment continues on .
Entry.161: - Captured same – on Bibe Wire lesson.
Entry.162: – Open order drill with full equipment – Moved off from Albert about 9-00 o’clock. Church completely ruined bronze statue hanging from Steeple – Slept in. Captured German trenches arriving hear about 12-00 – Artillery very active all the time - These trenches are nothing but a mass of ruin. Dugouts 30 feet deep dead all over the place some only covered over with a bit of dirt.
Entry.163: – Artillery still giving it to them – Went up and relieved
Entry.164:
Division who captured Pozieres – artillery active on both sides.

On
Entry.165: at 9-15 p.m. we charged the Germans capturing two lines of trenches and about 800 Prisoners. We held the trenches for 24 hrs. which were shelled very heavy and was relieved on
Entry.167:
Divis.

We marched to Warloy where we had a good sleep – We lost fairly heavy – stayed hear for one day & left following day – Camped about 10 miles away – left hear on
Entry.168: marched about 8 miles to Halloy Pernois where we are now billeted.
Entry.172:
Church Parade.

Left Halloy Pernois on
Entry.173: bivouaced in orchard for the night concert .
Entry.174: marched on to Vadencourt billetted in a wood about a 12 miles march this day.
Entry.176: Transferred to Brigade Machine Gunners at Harponcourt.
Entry.177:
Leaving hear about 1-00 o’clock arrived at Brickfield Hill near Albert about 5-30 – Stayed hear for the night.

Left hear on 21st marched to Sausage Gully – The Gunners went and relieved 2nd Brigade Gunners – On Guard over water cart 3rd Brigade captured 3 lines of trenches –
